Read 3 of the following chapters from Data Sketches by Shirley Wu and Nadieh Bremer:

- [Film Flowers](https://unl.alma.exlibrisgroup.com/leganto/public/01UON_LINC/citation/12340988500006387?auth=SAML)
- [My Life in Vacations](https://unl.alma.exlibrisgroup.com/leganto/public/01UON_LINC/citation/12340988610006387?auth=SAML)
- [Putting Emojis on the President's Face](https://unl.alma.exlibrisgroup.com/leganto/public/01UON_LINC/citation/12340988730006387?auth=SAML)
- [Magic is Everywhere](https://unl.alma.exlibrisgroup.com/leganto/public/01UON_LINC/citation/12340988810006387?auth=SAML)
- [Beautiful in English](https://unl.alma.exlibrisgroup.com/leganto/public/01UON_LINC/citation/12340988890006387?auth=SAML)

Annotate with hypothes.is (use the O'Reilly link through the library, please, so we all annotate the same thing.)

Think about/comment on: 

- How do these data visualizations differ from graphs made with e.g. ggplot2 or seaborn?
- Do you find these types of visualizations useful? aesthetically pleasing? fun?
